dialogues.speaker: SUNSET
dialogues.text: The glowing orb ripples like a blood-red eye.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, ROBED FIGURE
dialogues.text: A face of the ages. Dark, wrinkled skin. Wizened, almond eyes. He howls at the sun. His voice ECHOES across the sky. The Moslem call to prayer. Hundreds of feet below his tower, a mud-walled city of minarets and mosques. A human ants' nest. Scurrying to their devotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pervasive blackness. Moans of men in pain. Dripping water. Rats. Filth. The nadir of human degradation. Bedraggled white men, POWs from the Crusades, caged together with Arab cutthroats. Jailers wrench two crusaders from their cell. ROBIN OF LOCKSLEY and PETER DUBOIS. Their appearance reeks of long imprisonment, but remnants of their noble heritage still glimmer in their faces. Peter is so frail he can barely walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A furnace. Torture instruments glow red hot. Chained victims. A massive INTERROGATOR scrutinizes the two white men. Indicates a rat-faced lowlife, who points at Peter, jabbering in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says you stole his bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a lie. I caught him stealing ours. The lowlife jabbers some more.    The Interrogator debate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut off the infidel's hand. The jailers haul Peter to the chopping block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!... I took the bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not interested in truth. You are too weak, Peter. You would not live through it. The Interrogator stares into Robin's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacrifice for the weaker? How noble... As you wish... Cut off this one's hand as well!... But first... He indicates an Arab prisoner, who is dragged forward. His struggling hand is laid on the executioner's block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show them the courage of Allah. The prisoner's face braces for the pain. A red-hot scimitar flashes down. The hand flips into a basket. Twitching. Robin is next. His composure fails. He flops to his knees, crying. The Interrogator laughs. The jailers unlash the thongs on Robin's hand. They stretch it out, forcing it down. Robin goes limp, sobbing. Peter catches his eye... Robin winks. The scimitar. Drawn from the coals. Spitting flame. Arcs down. Robin is suddenly galvanized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is English courage. He hurls his holders aside. Swings upward, driving his fast into the executioner's throat. Grabs the sword. Slash. His thongs melt like butter. A jailer leaps at him. Steaming, the scimitar slices into the man's chest. Despite his bindings, Peter wrestles the Interrogator. Knife pressed to his throat, Peter is forced against the furnace. At the last second, he flips the man into the fire. Screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for five years of hell.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A jailer aims a scalding blade at Robin's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind you! Warned, Robin ducks away.    Slams the jailer's head into the wall. Peter frees himself, but they are still outnumbered. While fighting, Robin acknowledges the man who shouted the warning. An imposing, shaven-headed SARACEN. Heavily-muscled arms and chest, covered in tattoos. Even his bald head is ornamented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king's own. Set me free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For pity's sake. Mine is a sentence of death. Robin sidesteps, propelling a guard into a pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't trust him. Two more guards attack, yelling fury.    Robin eyes the curved scimitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I would give for an English sword. This is a pruning hook. A guard swings at him with a giant axe.    Robin slashes. shears the axe handle in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm!   Not bad. He runs the man through. Peter loses his sword. His opponent moves in for the kill... Peter grabs tongs from the fire and smolders his opponent with a backhand. Commotion outside.    RAISED VOICES and RUNNING FEET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free me and I will show you a way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should we trust you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't, you are dead men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a point. The door bursts open.    More guards rush in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good point. He slashes the man free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever blood is in his veins, he does not deserve to die here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way! He beckons them to the back.     A hidden door leads into tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wade through foul water up to their waists. The Saracen leads... A snake lashes out for his face. Robin lops off its head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are fast, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years I've waited for the smell of free air. That makes a man fast. Guards drop down from above, carrying torches.    Blockin the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will need to be yet faster. A narrow opening to their left... they splash through. Half running, half crawling in the dank water. Fire arrows land around them. The orange smoke is choking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poison air.   Hold your breath. Flames illuminate the walls, alive with a loathsome mass of crawling slime. Peter falls. A pursuer descends on him, thrusting a blazing torch at his face. The Saracen intercepts the blow. Grabs the man's neck, SNAPPING it with one mighty twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughing) Thanks. I misjudged you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your breath. Gasping for air, they find the tunnel veers steeply down- ward. A slippery, granite tube. Losing purchase, they slide headlong. Sharp, rusted spikes jut out from the walls ahead. Robin grabs at the walls to break the fall. No use. They're picking up speed. He turns his sword crossways, bracing it against the sides of the tunnel, as a brake. Sparks fly. The sword cuts into Robin's chest... but it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah be praised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen, brother. A bloodcurdling scream. A pursuing guard tumbles down the sewer chute. The three men press themselves against the wall. The man hurtles by... is impaled on the spikes. A draft of fresh air from the roof of the tunnel. Using the spiked guard as a ladder, Robin climbs. Removes a grating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin's head appears... ducks back down, as a squad of mounted soldiers thunders right over him... he reappears. All clear. They're outside the prison wall. Robin helps Peter up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God willing, we may now be safe.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Swoosh. An arrow pierces through Peter's chest -- fired from the prison wall. He reels... Robin leads him under the wall for protection. Shouts of alarm. Soldiers approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Peter.    We must hurry. Raising his sword, Peter faces the oncoming soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is mortal.    Leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on to my shoulder. Peter shakes him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother... my little sister. Tell them I love them. Tell them I died a free Englishman. Robin looks despairingly to the Saracen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wound is by the heart.    We cannot save him. Robin knows it's true. Peter pulls an insignia ring from a hidden pouch in his clothes. Thrusts it into Robin's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to my sister. Swear you will protect her for me... Swear it, Robin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) I swear it. Summoning hidden resources of strength, Peter charges at the oncoming soldiers, brandishing his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For England. He fells the first Arab.   The Saracen pulls Robin away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now! Do not fail your friend. Make his sacrifice an act of honor. They vanish into the night. Fighting like a man pos- sessed, Peter is swallowed in a sea of enemy soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: DESERTED ALLEY
dialogues.text: Robin and the Saracen catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farewell, friend. God speed you on your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our way is together. With the speed of Allah. He grins.    This strange man has a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I go to England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England?   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved my life. I must stay with you until I save yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go your own way. I relieve you of your obligation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Allah can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I don't want you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no choice... unless you think you can kill me. He grins broadly.      Offers his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Aslan. Resigned, Robin takes the proferred hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin of Locksley. You know a short route to England, Aslan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eerie shapes. Weaving. White light on water. The moon reflected in the moat of a small castle. Towers shrouded in night mist. Smoke curls from a chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRE CRACKLES in an open hearth. Hams and a half sheep hang, smoking. An old DOG SNORES at the fireside. A bone clunks on the floor, waking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough of that din, Remus.    I can't think. Licking the bone gratefully, the dog looks in the direc- tion of the voice... Grey. Proud. Distinguished. LORD LOCKSLEY. Seated at a table, wine goblet in hand, he pores   over a wonderful illustrated Bible. Reading to himself    for solace and strength. Empty chairs surround the    vast table. A deep sense of loneliness. He glances     at a portrait over the fireplace... Robin. The dog jumps. Hackles rise. O.S. SHOUTS. Locksley unsheathes a dagger. Obscures it in the folds of the Bible. The door bursts open. A peasant, ragged, desperate, KENNETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lord!   Help me. He's bleeding from a face wound. Another man grabs him from behind. Locksley's craggy-faced retainer, DUNCAN. Older than his master, but still strong, he holds Kenneth back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must wait... I am sorry you were disturbed, Master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high anxiety) My Lord, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is alright, Duncan. (to Kenneth) You are Kenneth of Cowfall? The peasant falls to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've taken my Gwen.    My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who has taken her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men on horses. In masks. (touches his wound) We tried to stop them. My son is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam pours from the nostrils of a black charger. Lord Locksley mounts, in armor. Duncan attempts to detain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot go alone, Master.      Let me ride for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be too late. Kenneth, lead the way. He kicks his horse into motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master, stay!    There is an evil moon tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good will overcome, Duncan.      Trust in that. Duncan looks up.    Crosses himself.    Dark clouds race across the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth checks the ground.    Locksley waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They came this way, my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onward then.    What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearby the Gregor Caves. Locksley reacts -- a hint of fear. They move on... Ahead, the hillside glows, rimmed in eerie light. Strange primitive CHANTS, wafted on the wind. Locksley ties his nervous horse to a tree. Parting undergrowth, Kenneth creeps forward. Cries out. He's face to face with the maggot-eaten skull of a goat. Beyond it, a gruesome host of half-skinned human skulls, all arranged on stakes. Some male, others with rotting female tresses, staring eyelessly into the night. Kenneth turns to run... A hand grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, man. They are to dissuade the faint of heart. Think of Gwen. From the crest of the rise, they peer down into the craggy valley. A cave opening, ablaze with flames leers at them like the mouth of hell. Before the cave, a circle of stones. A miniature Stonehenge. A medieval orgy. Men and women in masks and loose robes. Dancing. Drinking. Reveling. Pure carnality. Lord Locksley and Kenneth watch in horror. Faces ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Druids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trusted we were rid of such evil a century ago. An unearthly SCREECH. A creature leaps into the circle of stones. Grotesque gargoyle head, horns, fur-covered arms and legs. A living Hieronymous Bosch DEMON. Its clawed hands slash across a reveler's back, drawing blood in vicious streaks. The creature tastes the blood. The reveler is ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petrified) Is it the devil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is, I have some Christian steel that will test his hide. He draws his sword. A crucifix sculpted into the hilt. A girl is dragged from the cave. Kenneth buries his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gwen? Kenneth nods. The Demon shrieks, dervishing around GWEN, who  is carried onto the central plinth stone. A pagan   altar, the shape of an elephant's head with its trunk  raised. A masked figure stands at the head of the altar.   The high priest of the dark rite. The girl's body shudders as blood-red liquid is forced down her throat. The Demon's voice is husky and hideous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, my virgin flower. Hypnotized by the creature's voice and snake-like move- ments, Gwen stretches herself out. A single beam of sunlight slices through the mist, like a laser. The first light of the rising sun, it strikes directly on the altar, tracking down towards the girl's heart. The Demon's raised talons close in on the white flesh of her neck. Gwen's eyes are open wide, in a trance. The crowd of revelers encircle the plinth. Awed anticipation... A warrior's yell! Sword raised, Locksley THUNDERS in on his CHARGER. The terrified crowd parts. The Demon screams like a banshee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him!   Kill him! The followers throw themselves at   Locksley. He beats them off. The high priest issues    orders to armed guard who run to intercept. One aims a    spear. Locksley hacks the shaft in half. Cuts men down    left and right. Reaches the altar stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gwen!   Up, girl, up! Gwen shakes off her trance. The Demon launches itself at Locksley. Talons rip flesh from his face. With all his strength, Locksley hurls the creature down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of God! His broadsword swings in a mighty arc. Slices across the gargoyle's skull. Clean through half the face... Impossibly, the demon rolls back to its feet.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The head is an elaborate mask -- beneath are the yellow skin, white hair, and burning red eyes of an albino crone. Screaming vitriol, the hag is unharmed. Momentarily stunned, Locksley regains his senses, hauls the girl onto his charger. The guards close in. Locksley spurs his horse. Rides for an opening. The masked high priest stands resolutely in his path. Brandishing a burning branch. The horse is freaked. Rears. Locksley and the girl are thrown. Unarmed, Locksley charges the man. Slams him into the cave wall. The mask falls. Locksley gasps in recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nottingham! The SHERIFF OF NOTTINGHAM. Powerful build, black beard, cruel intensity in every feature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are an unwelcome surprise, Locksley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King shall hear of this, Nottingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think not. Locksley is surrounded. One by one the men reveal their faces. Locksley backs up in shock, recognizing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day all England will worship with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never. The crone spits venom in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Mortianna. You will die with my name on your lips. Locksley's agonized cry fills the valley. On the hill- side, Kenneth averts his eyes. Turns to run. Five masked figures block his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A twelfth century French sailboat at anchor.    A cross o its sail. A longboat rows to shore. Robin stands in the prow, in a pilgrim's hooded robe. He gazes at the approaching land. Unable to wait, he leaps into the surf and wades to the beach. He kneels, pressing his hands and face into the soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.    Thank you, Lord. Aslan steps from the boat, sniffing the air. The French sailors keep their distance from him. Robin takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend, you have escorted me home. I beg you to free yourself of your vow. Return with the boat. I know how heavy your heart must be, this far from your family and native land...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I love them so dearly, I cannot dishonor them. A sailor creeps up behind Aslan, club in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd say that. He nods to the sailor, who swings the club down. The Saracen sidesteps, grabs the man's arm and flips him into the surf. He turns a cold stare on Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No man controls my destiny. Especially not one who attacks downwind and stinks of garlic. Robin laughs.    The Saracen remains intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If our positions were reversed, I would have done the same. Only I would have succeeded. He smiles broadly.    Robin claps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Aslan. By nightfall we will celebrate your honor when we dine with my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH! An armored foot splinters the door of a farmer's hovel. Children scream and run. A soldier clubs at them, laughing. Outside. More soldiers. Some on horses, others on foot, with leashed hounds. Pillaging. Vandalizing. Searching. GUY GISBORNE: An impressive figure on horseback. Strikingly handsome -- except that one of his ears is missing. We recognize his face from the Druid ceremony. He coldly addresses a pregnant woman with a child in her arms, FANNY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe the sheriff three bushels of flax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You starve us. First the drought, now you take what food we have left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For starving people, you look fat enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emerging from the hut) He's not here, sir. None but the woman and children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fanny) Where is your mate? The man they call Little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died last winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? We hear he     is very much alive. Hiding out     in the forest. He probably ran     away to escape your scolding    tongue. The soldiers join in his laughter. Incensed, Fanny pounds her fist on his legs. Gisborne kicks her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman swine! A BOY of 12 springs from nowhere, thrusting a hay fork at Gisborne's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Wulf! Don't! 'Twill only make it worse. Wulf backs off.   Nostrils flaring with repressed hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seize him! While two soldiers grab the Boy, others examine his hiding place. A secret thatched door, built into the side of a haystack... a bow and quiver... and a deer carcass. Gisborne dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Lord Nottingham's deer. Is this how you repay the Sheriff for his protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a wolf protects sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed it.   We needed the meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poachers hang. Either he dies or you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother lies to protect me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Wulf! Gisborne drags the boy to the carcass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have deprived us of a hunt, boy. He cups his hand in the deer's blood.    Smears it on Wulf's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hounds know the scent well. He tosses his bloody glove to the dogs. They tear at each other in their effort to rip at the glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run, boy. Like a deer. Give us some pleasure before you die.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: To the accompaniment of the HOUNDS' savage HOWLS and the horrified screams of his family, Wulf runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unleash them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearing home, Robin is buoyant.     The Saracen, brooding walks two paces behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must you walk in back of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your land am I not the infidel? The unbeliever, the instrument of evil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our races have fought for a hundred years to prove that point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I trust it is safer to appear as your slave than as your equal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an 'infidel' you have uncommon clarity of thinking. Yet you refuse to tell me about your home and family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my burdens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak my language. You have the diplomacy and honor code of a nobleman. I ask again, why were you to be executed? The Saracen maintains a moody silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I must continue with my guesswork. You are highborn? Probably... You fell from favor... Clearly... Why? You broke the law? You were a rival for power? ... A woman?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Saracen reacts, almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the Lord, that's it! Aslan is silent, but Robin knows he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say there are Arab women of such beauty that they can possess a man's mind, that he would be willing to die for them. Is that not so? Ignoring him, the Saracen stops.      Examines the darken sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is close to sunset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your people must marry women chosen for them by others, right? No reply.    Aslan unfolds a prayer rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she? The Mullah's daughter? ... Another man's wife?... That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endless clouds. Is there no sun in your cursed country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dog! You painted old dog! What is her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way is East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: East?!!! Robin folds his arms.    A standoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you!... Jasmina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jasmina!    Is she beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way is East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way. Aslan throws his rug on the ground.    Kneels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would know blindfolded. I'm five miles from home... Was she worth it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worth dying for. Robin stands smiling over him as Aslan begins his prayers... BAYING of HUNTING DOGS... In the distance, the boy Wulf runs toward them, ducks behind a tree and clubs the leading dog with a branch. The other hounds close in... panting with exhaustion, Wulf swings into the branches. A hound savages his leg. The soldiers surround the tree. The boy clambers precariously onto the highest branch... Robin surrep- titiously steals a crossbow from one of the soldiers' horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not playing by    the rules, boy. Deer don't climb     trees... Perhaps he thinks he's    a game bird. Shall we teach     him to fly? Cut it down! The soldiers hack at the trunk.    The tree quivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold!... I am curious as to what manner of creature is so fearsome that it takes six men to attack it. Shrouded in his pilgrim's hooded cloak, he approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back, stranger. This is no affair of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we treed the devil himself? Let me see... Ah ha! A small boy. A truly dangerous animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I advise you to move on, pilgrim. This is the Sheriff's land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. This is my land, and my tree. Therefore, whatever is in it also belongs to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grow dangerously tired of your wit... Chop it down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who strikes that tree dies. He glances nervously at Aslan, who's still at his prayers. The men stop in mid-swing. More surprised than scared. Gisborne gestures to the largest of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chop down the hooded fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing up) Perhaps we could discuss this. The soldier raises his sword. Robin lifts his cape... the crossbow. Shoots from the hip. The bolt thuds through the man's armor. He's dead before he lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aslan!   It's time to redeem that vow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set the dogs on him!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Aslan ignores him, lost in his   prayers. Robin lifts the other arm -- a second concealed   crossbow. WHUMPF! The bolt flips the dog handler into   the vicious pack. Dead or not, he soon will be. Robin    unsheathes his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aslan, get off your damn knees! I have four of them cornered. The Saracen remains head down. Or did we see him steal a glance? Gisborne signals his men to attack. A wave of flashing steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope there's enough of me to satisfy you all. Backed up to a tree, he grabs a branch and kicks out. Two men fly back. He lunges at a third. His sword strikes flesh. Robin sidesteps and hurls the fourth onto a sharp tree stump. Gisborne thrusts. Robin reacts too slowly.       Blood fl from his arm. His sword falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aslan!! Gisborne is on him, sword pressed to his back.      Robin freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hooded stranger, allow me to know your name before I run you through. A moment of silence... Like lightning, Robin spins, kicks out Gisborne's legs. Slams one foot on the man's sword arm, the other on his throat. Throws back his pilgrim's hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin of Locksley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your knees, Gisborne.   Pray. He obeys.    Robin raises his sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Locksley! No! Robin drives the point into Gisborne's rear.      The man leaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get off my land. And tell your cousin the Sheriff what happens to his scum when they pick on my people. Gisborne takes off, colliding with Aslan as he folds his rug. Reacts in shock at the sight of the strange Arab. Keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Aslan, furious) You worthless savage! You travel ten thousand miles to save my life, then leave me to be butchered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will fulfill my vow when I choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which does not include prayer times, meal times, or any time I'm outnumbered six to one!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You whine like a mule.   You are still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely. Aslan examines Robin's wound.   Dismissive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flesh wound. Why did you let their leader go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After six years of the stench of death, I have no stomach for needless blood on my hands. Wulf climbs cautiously from the tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have no fear, boy. The boy nervously eyes Robin and the Saracen, fingering a crucifix around his neck. Runs off into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) The conquering hero returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!   It was you he was scared of. Aslan's humor is infectious.     Robin's anger relents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, my strange friend. Beyond that hill lies the prettiest little castle in all Christendom. Warm hearths, hot food, real beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With feather pillows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With feather pillows. Warm and soft like Jasmina's embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruins. The moon hovers ominously over the once-proud castle. Burned to the ground. Gutted and deserted. Towers demolished. Moat drained. Robin stares, struck dumb with horror. The dark courtyard.   Heartsick, Robin stumbles over debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father!    Hello! His VOICE ECHOES around the fallen battlements. Aslan places a hand on his shoulder and points... Suspended high on a tower wall is a decaying human corpse.

dialogues.speaker: MEDALLION
dialogues.text: round the corpse's neck.   The Locksley crest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooo! A paroxysm of rage and grief. He smashes furniture. Slams his fists relentlessly into the wall. Pained, Aslan looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have been here. Spent, he leans against the wall. In the silence, they hear an eerie TAPPING. Robin draws his sword... A hunched, old man emerges, walking with the aid of a staff ... Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking him) Damn you, Duncan. Why didn't you cut him down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Robin, is it you? A miracle. I thought God had abandoned us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left my father to hang like a common thief, carrion for the crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy... Look at him. Duncan steps into the moonlight.    His face crudely- scarred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say they captured him worshipping with the Druids. He signed a confession before the Bishop of Hereford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they have witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one. Kenneth of Cowfall. The Bishop decreed all the Locksley lands forfeit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you believe the charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even when they took my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did this to you, Duncan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy of Gisborne. With the sheriff looking on. Robin holds the old retainer to his chest.    Stares into the night in silent rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marked contrast.   A forbidding fortress.   Cliff-like battlements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face like thunder, Guy of Gisborne strides up curving, stone steps. A long corridor leads to a guarded oak door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Guy. His Lordship is not to be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away, fool. He shoves the Sentry aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torches illuminate Nottingham's face. Chilling cruelty in Manson-like eyes. Seated, his manicured hand dis- tractedly strokes a semi-naked girl. She sits at his feet like a frightened dog. When Gisborne enters, she covers up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who bade you cover up? He smashes his fist into his chair.   She timidly uncovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin, I trust you justify your intrusion with news of profound value. His attention is riveted on a dark niche in the corner of the courtyard. UNEARTHLY SOUNDS emanate from the black- ness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met a hooded man today. He bade me warn you not to harm his people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin of Locksley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! The prodigal son returns. He is a whelp. This girl could best him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whelp bested five of my men in the blink of an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your men were probably drunk.   Yet you survived, cousin? Heavy scorn. The sheriff pats Gisborne's hand like a child's. The voice from the darkness becomes a loud CHANT. A wrinkled, monkey-like figure dances INTO VIEW, wearing a necklace of human fingers. You might think she was a hundred years old, if not for her incredible agility. MORTIANNA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) You brought her here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet! The crone's fingers dart into a bag. Emerge with a writhing, SQUEALING mass... a PIGLET. A knife flashes. Blood spurts into an ornate, sacred platter. The girl flinches in horror. Mortianna shakes the con- tents of a pouch across the bloody dish. Carved bone dice -- Runes. She rattles the platter. The rune symbols dance in trails of blood. Eyes vacant, mouth frothing, she hisses out her incoherent visions. Nottingham follows her every move. A connoisseur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change the seat of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move the capitol to Nottingham? Excellent. How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally with royal blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put someone on the throne and rule through him? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not revealed. The idea takes shape in Nottingham's mind.      Mounting intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ally with royal blood. What else do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours. Men and weaponry in great numgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And victory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much blood will be spilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dice splashes blood. Lands -- a death's head symbol. Mortianna hammers the platter. The dice spins and lands again. Again the grinning skull.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The tray smashes to the ground.      The hag runs at Gisborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who have you seen?! She shakes him.    Screams spittle in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freaked) No one. I have seen no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie!     A man... A painted man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen my death. She whimpers.   Spins, as if fearing invisible intruders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The painted man. He haunts my dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locksley has a companion. A dark- skinned foreigner. He had the marked skin of Islam. Mortianna trembles like an epileptic.    Eyes wide with terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill them!     Kill them! She throws herself at Nottingham for protection.    He caresses her. Gisborne is thunderstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cousin. Prove to Locksley that your survival was his last mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantic) And the painted man! Kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill them both. He continues to stroke her.    Her trembling subsides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done well, Mortianna. Exceedingly well. No one shall harm you, I swear it. Mortianna reaches out bloodied fingers towards the young girl, who shrinks away. Nottingham gently takes the girl's hand.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Draws it to his mouth, as if to kiss it... and bites down viciously, drawing blood. The girl screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my child, Mortianna's kisses will seem soft, like an angel's. (to Mortianna) Take her. You have earned her. Mortianna grabs the terrified girl's wrist.   Drags her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is madness bringing the hag here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear not for my sanity, Guy. For in madness, there is great power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red shards of sunlight slice through mist-shrouded trees. Robin hammers a crude cross over a hillside grave. Heads bowed, Duncan and Aslan stand at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our last words in this world were spoken in anger. He called the Crusades a foolish quest, said it was vanity to force other men to our religion. He was right. (looks to Aslan, then back to the grave) Please forgive me, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved you till the end, young master. He never gave up hope of your return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I failed him. I should have been here at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must leave, head north to safety. Gisborne will surely seek revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're thinking. But one man can achieve nothing against so many. You would need an army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, friend. He leads the old man away.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE SIDE
dialogues.text: Pouring rain. Robin stands drenched at the grave side. Aslan watches from the shelter of trees. Duncan heats a stale chunk of bread over the ashes of a small fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still stands vigil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a rock. Duncan offers half the bread to the Saracen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A curse on the Saracens! Were it not for their ungodly ways, he would never have left. This would never have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It surprises me that one who curses others so readily has lived so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not recognize the style of your voice, friend. Are you Irish? A Cornishman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What manner of name is Aslan then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine Saracen name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, no! He chokes in shock.   Spitting bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, yes. But eat in peace. I take no offense. (glances at Robin) By the prophet! What is the man doing? Robin raises his dagger over his wrist.   Aslan runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Too late. Robin slashes the dagger across his palm. Rain and blood mingle. Streaming onto the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear by my own blood. I will not rest until I have restored my father's name. (a whisper) ... Or until I am dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooze sucks at feet.   The three men stomp through mud and rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make a fine army, do we not, Duncan? A blind man, an Arab, and a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine, wet army. I have never witnessed a storm of such duration. When does summer come to this land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Allah truly is great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, pray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No food, no shelter,   and weather that would curse the   end of the earth. We  will all   quickly be dead, and I shall be   rid of my vow. They approach a stone wall, surrounding a thatched mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You despair too soon, Aslan. We shall find food and shelter here among friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's home. It is nearly seven years since we left here together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin pounds on the door.    A hatch opens.     An OLD WO face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No beggars! The hatch slams shut.    Robin pounds again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open up! A pause.   The hatch slides back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the mistress of the house that Robin of Locksley is at her door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her ladyship is not at home. She slams the hatch again.    Robin jams in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aagh! He shouts through the hatch, over his bruised fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the child Marian at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she is. Maybe she isn't. Remove that hand. Robin refuses. She waits imperiously behind the locked door. Robin reluctantly withdraws his hand. Instantly the hatch slams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospitality here is as warm as the weather. They wait, shivering... The door opens a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave your weapons. The three start forward.       Her bony finger points at Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall. Deer heads.        Boar heads.   Portraits of ancestors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. He waits.    CREAKING FOOTSTEPS on the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Dim lighting.    Robin cannot make out who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Robin of Locksley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie.     Robin is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may meet my maker soon from lack of sustenance. But for now I am real enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step into the light.    Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By heaven, am I to dance next? Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the maid Marian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then show yourself, child.     For we knew each other well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the king away, these are lawless times. There are outlaws villainous enough to kidnap and ransom a relative of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I am not one of them. Besides, I am sworn to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Protect me? Robin of Locksley was nothing but a spoiled bully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow that years of war and prison may change a man. Step forward, Marian, so I may see how you have changed. She moves into the light... Fat.     Rotten teeth.   Ugly sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... the years have been kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now remove yourself from this household. A figure steps behind Robin.    Sticks a sword in his bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away) As you can see, we are already well protected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, Marian!    ...ouch!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The sword is jabbed into his back. Robins faces the man -- clad in back, with a metal fighting mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are truly courageous against an unarmed man. The figure gestures towards the door. Robin sidesteps. Slams an elbow. The sword drops. Slides across the floor. Robin moves for it, but the man intercepts, drawing a dagger. Robin darts to the wall. Rips off an antlered deer head. Defends himself as the attacker slashes at the horns.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the fight indoors.   Aslan hurls himself at the door. It doesn't give.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Chunks of horn fly. Robin parries and thrusts.     The horns get shorter. Robin retreats. Left with just the nubs, Robin hurls the deer head at the mask. Gaining advantage, he charges. Grabs the dagger hand, smashes it into the wall. The knife drops. Robin wrenches off the mask. Long hair tumbles down... a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN. The front door CAVES IN. Aslan stumbles through... just in time to see the woman's knee fly up into Robin's crotch. Robin folds. The battle is over. The young woman stands over Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she was saying, we have no need of your protection. Robin croaks through clenched teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liquid tumbles into a goblet.   The three men at a table in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The fat girl, SARAH, who pretended to be Marian, serves. Flashes a lusty smile at Aslan, who glances at Robin -- "Help!" Marian arrives. In a gown. Stunning. An impish grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust Lord Locksley has recovered from his indisposition. Aslan laughs.   Robin glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock-strewn hills. Grazing sheep. Sun peeking through clouds. Robin and Marian walk. Anger and anguish in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he wish me to be protected by the boy who burned my hair when I was a child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were together five terrible years in a Saracen prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you didn't abandon him there to save your own skin. Robin hands her Peter's ring.   She is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marian, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will forward your condolences to my mother. She turns her back.   He searches for a way to reach her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my return, I found my father dead. The Sheriff denounced him as a Druid and took our lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people fear the Druids so much they'd believe anything. Nottingham would have me burned at the stake as a witch if he thought he could possess my property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you not join your mother in London? You would be safer there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not retreat.     Besides, I have no interest in    life at court. Gossip-mongering and    currying favor. Here I am my     own person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The you must allow me to be your guardian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not need a guardian. She turns to face him.   Streaming tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is dead. You cannot take his place. Robin grabs and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marian, I don't want to replace him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? Their eyes meet... a sudden intimacy between them. Robin moves closer. Marian begins to respond, then pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is wrong. She runs back to the house. Robin stares after her. Aslan appears in the doorway with Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin! The old man hears horses. Approaching fast. He runs to a bluff... a column of soldiers snakes up the hillside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty or more. In battle armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers coming here?     Is this your protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed some of the Sheriff's men. I fear I have placed you in danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of myself. There are horses in the stable. Go! Aslan runs into the stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving. Marian ices him with a glare. Aslan reappears, with two bareback horses. Soldiers appear on the crest, led by Gisborne... With a mischievous grin, Marian runs to the soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop them!   They're stealing my horses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn the girl! Aslan, can you ride? In answer, Aslan grins. Leaps onto a horse. With a single swift move he hoists Duncan up behind him and digs in his heels. The mare leaps forward, and over the estate wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can ride. He heads his horse at the wall. It stumbles. Barely clears it. Stones fly. Robin struggles to hold on. Marian stands directly in Gisborne's path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been sheltering outlaws, Lady Marian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're thieves, you imbecile. Bring back my horses, or the Sheriff will know of your cowardice. Gisborne knows she is lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky he didn't steal your virtue too. (to his men) A crown to the man who brings me Locksley's head. He leads the pursuit.   A SOLDIER hangs back.   Grabs Marian's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kiss for me, Saxon bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss this! She unsheathes the dagger from under her skirt.    Jabs the blade into his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try me again, if you want to leave a hand behind. Shocked and pained, the man gallops away. Marian looks down at her dagger hand. It shakes violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water erupts under hooves. Aslan fords a stream. Duncan hangs on for dear life. Robin strives to keep up. Half a mile behind Gisborne splits up his men. Trying for a short cut, Robin finds himself at the steepest part of the river gorge. His horse balks at the drop. Robin flails at his mount with hands and feet. It backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, animal! Aslan shouts from the far bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Treat it like a woman. Robin continues to hit his horse and hurl abuse. Closing in, the soldiers unfurl their crossbows. A flight of BOLTS WHISTLES ominously close to Robin. He must jump or die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you never had a woman? Gently, man. Soothe it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I've had a woman! Come on, pretty one. He pats the horse soothingly.    The animal edges forward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Softly.   With your knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know!   I know! The soldiers reload.   Robin urges the horse at the steep drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, easy. Another wave of crossbow bolts. Robin launches the frightened animal into space. Hooves flail... touch down. Scramble up the other bank. Robin enthusiastically pats the horse's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you! The first two pursuers misjudge their leaps.     Their mounts land sprawling in the riverbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Robin of the Hood! Son of the devil worshipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your pleasure, Gisborne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was I who strung your father's corpse to the castle gate. My pleasure will be in doing the same to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived one meeting.    Our next will be your last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father died a coward, cursing your name and squealing like a stuck pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Incensed, he is losing his judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Robin! He is trying to anger you into a trap. A shaft pierces the flank of Robin's horse. It rears in fright. Robin clings on. Six soldiers, the men Gisborne split off, are climbing the embankment towards him. Robin regains control. Rides right at them. Scatters them, and takes off again. Gisborne yells at his men to follow. Robin and Aslan ride flat out. Open land turns to scrub. Seeing no followers, Robin pulls up and dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have lost them. I'll lame this mare if I ask her to go any farther. He gently extracts the shaft from his horse. Aslan opens his pouch. Pulls out two shiny clear pebbles and a square leather hide. Rolls the pebbles into the tube and holds it to his eye. A primitive telescope. Robin watches, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the scope we see the movement on the hill behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come. Look. Robin puts the device to his eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers are close!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: He reacts in shock. Prepares to defend himself.    Then realizes they are still in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Arab magic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Arab science. He replaces the tube in his pouch. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did your uneducated kind ever take Jerusalem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God knows! Aslan laughs.   Robin points towards an endless expanse o trees. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can lose them in the forest. DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherwood is haunted, Master. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either we take our chances with the ghosts, or become ghosts ourselves. He remounts. They race into the trees. Gisborne's men thunder up,... slowing as they enter the forest. Peering around them in trepidation, they slowly rein in. Robin looks back. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not following. Gisborne curses his men, urging them on. GISBORNE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, damn you! There are only three of them. SOLDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the men we fear, sir. Eerie HOWLING and RATTLING of bones.    Aslan draws his sword. DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banshees. They say they fly in your mouth and suck you dry of blood before you can scream. He wraps his scarf over his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet!    Listen. WIND GUSTS the trees in angry waves. Emits deathly SHRIEKS. The HORSES WHINNEY. Unnerved, Aslan smites around him with his scimitar. Wheels at the sounds, striking only air. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah protect us from the evil spirits. Duncan clings to his back.   Robin points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind you! Aslan slashes out, futilely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there!    And there! Aslan flails.   Robin cracks up. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cease your mad laughing.     I can feel them. Robin reaches into the branches. Pulls out a string of hollowed wooden tubes -- WINDCHIMES. Dozens of such strings on all the trees. He blows over the hollow end. A low chilling MOAN. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are your ghosts, Duncan. A child's toy put to good use. You scare easily, my painted Saladin. His laughter is broken by a piercing YELL. A red- jacketed figure swings down out of a tree on a rope. Catapults him to the ground. The bushes are instantly alive. Shaggy, wild-eyed men, armed with cudgels, scythes and hayforks. Twelfth- century Hell's Angels. The red-jacketed young turk, WILL SCARLET, leaps around Robin. WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Ring around the rosie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aslan! Aslan makes no move to intervene.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The woodsmen eye the bizarre stranger, keeping their distance from him. Will kicks at Robin, who tries to grab him. Will skips out of range. Robin falls. WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atishoo, Atishoo. We all fall down. Beg for mercy, rich man. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg of no man. Which of you scum has guts enough to face me man to man? VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, bollocks, mate. Robin looks up... I mean up! A towering figure. Seven feet of grinning, muscled brute. The giant extends a vice that passes for a hand. Hauls Robin to his feet. His eyes twinkle with merriment. His whole body shakes when he laughs, which is often. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are ya, m'old cock? ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er... Robin... He pauses, checking the faces of the angry peasants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hood.   Robin Hood.   Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Little.   Bestman o' the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bestman?   You lead this rabble? WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We waste time. Tax him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tax?   For what? WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For passage through Sherwood. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will pay no tax. Besides, I have nothing but my cloak and my sword.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who travels with two servants and claims he's without money, is either a fool or a liar. Grabbing Robin, Little shakes him like a doll. Something CLINKS. Robin's father's medallion. Laughing heartily, Little rips it from Robin's neck and tosses it to Scarlet WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this one is a liar. (he bites the metal) Ahah! Gold! The men cheer.   John snatches the medallion back from Will. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is sacred to me. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacred to us too, mush. This here'll feed us for a bloomin' month. Robin draws his sword. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have to fight me for it. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, mate. He grins hugely.   A boy pushes his way through the thron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, father!    I know him. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is your father? Tell him how I saved your hide from the Sheriff's soldiers. That deserves some gratitude, I believe. He reaches for the medallion.    John pulls it away. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw ya don't, laddie. WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Robin of Locksley. The blackguard who abandoned us to Nottingham's plundering.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WULF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful, Father. He fights like a demon. He walloped six o' Sheriff's men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so? Another grin. Licking his lips in anticipation, he lunges for Robin's wrist. Wrenches the sword free. Bends it into a pretzel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aslan! Aslan shrugs. Robin swings a fist into the giant's gut. John doesn't flinch. Hoists Robin off the ground with one arm. Cannonballs the other fist into Robin's stomach. Robin folds. WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear! The little rich boy is lost for words. Thanks for the taxes, Locksley. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for the laughs. The woodsmen find this hysterical. They disappear into the tree. Will administers one final kick before leaving. Robin staggers to his feet. Glares furiously at Aslan. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of an Arab whore! Once again your assistance was invaluable. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seemed more in danger of losing your pride than your life. DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recognized some of the voices. Many were from your father's farms. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your avenging army, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That rabble? ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All they need is a leader.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a leader.   A very large one. ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Defeat him and they will follow you. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah has taken your brains. DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear the voice of a spoiled child, Master Robin. I suggest you cease your brave talk of revenge and flee to the north. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too? You expect me to fight that behemoth? DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father would expect you to act like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large tree trunk spans a swift-flowing river. The ragged band of woodsmen approach the makeshift bridge. Stop in their tracks. Robin stands on the bridge, brandishing a long wooden staff. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my bridge. No one crosses without paying tax. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just bugger off, mate, huh? ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wish to cross, it will cost you a gold medallion. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't I hurt you a bloody nuff for one day? WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's in a hurry to end his mortal misery, help him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have the courage to face me again, John Little? Or should I call you 'Little John'? John grabs a hefty, gnarled staff.   Strides to the bridge. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, m'old cock. You wanna nuther good wallopin'? His confidence melting, Robin glances back at Duncan and Aslan, who grins like a fan at a boxing match. John storms at Robin. Staffs thrash. Driven back, Robin connects a blow on John's foot. The giant is off-balance. Robin follows up. Lands a couple to the ribs. John responds with heavy swings, which Robin blocks deftly. Back and forth, blow for blow, all blocked. John chuckles with every swing. Enjoying the time of his life. Their staffs lock. It's strength against strength. Robin is no match. With one mighty thrust, John hurtles him into the stream. The woodsmen cheer loudly. Aslan watches impassively. Robin scrambles back onto the bridge.   John waits, grinning. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lil' wet behind the ears, mate? WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fool with him. Get him! John charges. Robin fends him off, gets in some shots of his own. John swings in a giant arc. Robin ducks. John loses balance and falls to his knees. Robin allows him time to right himself. John comes at him again, pummeling. Wood splinters from the impact. Brute force versus agility. Agility is beginning to prevail, when Robin's staff splits in two. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimmin' time again, ol' chum. The coup de grace. Lands heavily. Robin teeters. Falls. Disappears under the foaming water... does not re-emerge. John waits. The spectators rush to the bank. No sign.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloomin' shame. 'E were a brave 'un. Suddenly Robin arcs up out of the water. His hands clamp onto John's ankles. Robin heaves with all his might. John topples headfirst into the water. Surfaces in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!   Cain't bloody swim. He submerges again.   Robin pulls his head above water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you yield? The terrified giant sputters. Goes under again, flailing with arms and legs. Robin holds his head just above the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you yield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   Now put your feet down. John struggles, then his feet hit bottom... The water only reaches his chest. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be buggered. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay me the tax. A tense pause while all wait for Little's reaction. JOHN LITTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin Hood, ya got balls o' solid rock. He hands Robin back the medallion. Chuckling loudly, he swoops Robin up in his arms and carries him to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BONFIRE CRACKLES. The woodsmen drink, eat, argue, and fight. A rabble. John passes Robin a jug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead.   Made it m'self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine brew, Little John. He spits black objects from his mouth.      Dead bees. grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real honey. He takes the jug back. Sneezes royally, spewing all over the brew. Oblivious, he hands the contaminated jug to Aslan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With regrets, I decline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Englishman's mead not bleedin' good enough for ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary. I thank you, but my faith prevents me from partaking in such enjoyments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bloody loss, mate. He swigs.    Passes the jug on to Duncan, who drinks heartily.    Wulf cautiously approaches Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, boy? Speak up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna thankee, Lord Locksley. I owes ya m'life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me nothing, Wulf. I am glad I chanced by in time to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, lad, drink! 'Twill put hair on your bloomin' chest. Wulf tries the brew. The impact is instant.       He turn green and runs. His father cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about your men, John. John points to a short fellow with the build of a tree trunk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stumpy one 'ere's David o' Doncaster. We calls 'im Bull. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you come by the name, Bull? BULL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cuz o' my size, Sire. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you are short?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.   'Cuz I be so long. Proudly, he starts to pull down his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bull.    Save it for the ladies. Drunken laughter.    Robin turns to the next man at the fireside. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name, friend? The man's bald pate blushes scarlet as he tries to respond, but he stutters too badly to get out a comprehensible word. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That be Hal Brownwell, but the lads call i'm Hal Hiccup. The others make hiccup and belching sounds, and crack up at Hal's embarrassment. Hal strikes out angrily at his tormentors. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold! Hal, you have the face and hands of a farmer. I wager you are a strong and honest man, and I'd be glad to have you at my side in a fight. The next man who makes light of you will have to answer to me. There is murmuring around the group, but no one elects to try it. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it there are so many of you in hiding?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're outlaws. Got prices on our 'eads, every man jack. Blasted Sheriff says we owes 'im taxes. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you fare? LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get by, I reckon. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the Sheriff steals your land and your families starve? LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in bloody blazes'd ya have us do? ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your ghosts will only keep his men at bay so long, my friend. Soon the Sheriff will hunt you down and hang you. You must fight back. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We show as much as a toe outside the forest, they'll slaughter us like bleedin' sheep. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must organize. Win by guile. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'We'? Ya lookin' to join us, matie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   To lead you. WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! I would never be led by the son of a Druid. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many here who knew my father to be a kind and generous man. I doubt that in their hearts they believe him capable of such a horror. Murmurs of agreement from around the fire.    Robin turns to Will.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name, friend? WILL SCARLET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count me not a friend, Locksley. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuff a flippin' cork in it, Will. The man's our guest. Will gets up.   Angrily pushes his way out of the group. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That there's Will Scarlet. Pay 'im no 'eed. 'E's full o' piss and wind. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is right to distrust me. I am a rich man's son. I have done no honest labor. But today I am as poor as any of you. Nottingham has stolen all that I own. And when I killed Gisborne's men, I, too, became an outlaw. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya're full o'bloody wind an' all, mate. This 'ere load o' rubbish agin the Sheriff's bloomin' army? Ya must be bloody jokin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can win.   And I believe we will. LITTLE JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya're a daft bugger, Robin Hood, but ya're a brave 'un, I'll give ya that. Drink up, laddie, cuz tomorrow ya mayn't be so lucky! Tomorrow I shall best ya an' crack that blasted noble head in two. Laughing loudly, he throws back his head for a long draught of mead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steady trickle of RAIN drips from leaves onto the nose of the sleeping Saracen. He wakes, cursing. All around him the woodsmen lie on the forest floor, covered with rags and hides coughing and sneezing. A sorry mess. Robin sits, brooding.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ASLAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gloomily) I have led you wrong. This is no army. These men live like dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English dogs.    They can learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn what?   To build kennels? He sullenly stalks away. Robin shakes his head. Aslan is right. He rouses Duncan, who is asleep at his side. The old man groans awake, holding his head. Seriously hung-over. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too much mead, old friend.    What day is it? DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday, I believe. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Do they still give alms to the poor at the mass? DUNCAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do. These days the need for mercy is greater than ever. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I must ask you a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan walks alone, with the aid of his staff. Body stooped, clothes ragged, a pathetic figure. Ahead is the main gate to the walled city of Nottingham. Fresh horse manure. A man's hand reaches into it and spreads it over his clothes. And his face -- Robin, dressed as Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin taps his way through the crowd. Past the piercing stare of the armored GUARD at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you! Robin keeps going.   A hand clasps his shoulder.    Spins him 'round.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know you? Robin gazes into space, trying to look blind.   The Guard sniffs his soiled hand. GUARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, you stink! ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon my blindness, sir.    I'm always falling down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeech!   Get away from me. He launches a kick in Robin's rear. Robin hobbles away, hiding a smile. The Guard tries to wipe off his hand on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus hangs from the cross. A magnificent stained glass window. In the ornate pulpit, the BISHOP OF HEREFORD, bedecked in ermine. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We beseech thy blessing, Lord, on all your people, but most especially on our noble Lord Nottingham. Grant him the wisdom to guide and protect our glorious city. Nottingham and Gisborne sit piously among the congrega- tion of nobles and wealthy merchants. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant him also the strength to bring to justice the lawless men who threaten its safety. Help him to stamp out the curse of the dread Druids who would seize from us our children, even as wolves steal the lambs from their mothers. The rear of the church. Standing crushed together, the poor and afflicted. Old and young. Starving children. Among them, Robin. The sermon ends. As the nobles file out, the poor are galvanized. Begging hands reach out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1.   Alms! 2.   Have mercy, milady. 3.   Pity, fine sir. 4.   For my baby. 5.   Etc. The rich drop a few mites, sparking a mad scramble. Church officials roughly keep order. Marian passes some coins to the mother of a small child. A hand grabs her wrist. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alms for a blind man. For one who cannot see your beauty. MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing him) This is dangerous. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you care for my safety? MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for mine. I do not wish to be seen with an outlaw. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the Sheriff's law, that's a badge of pride. MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's put a price on your head. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much? MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred gold pieces. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all? I have not annoyed him enough. Soon he will offer ten thousand. MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For ten thousand I would turn you in myself. (glances back at the Sheriff) Nottingham is mounting an army. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has rounded up every blacksmith in the county. He has them holed up in the castle making swords and armor. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he planning? MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but there's no limit to the man's ambitions. (as Sheriff heads towards them) Go! ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need me, I will be with the woodsmen. Send for me as 'Robin Hood.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin!   Do something for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a bath. ROBIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
